**Commentary on the *Scripture of the Natural Nine Heavens’ Chapters on Generating the Divine* from the *Dongxuan Lingbao***

**Title:** *Commentary on the* Scripture of the Natural Nine Heavens’ Chapters on Generating the Divine *from the* Dongxuan Lingbao
**Author:** Hua Yangfu of the Yuan dynasty
**Volumes:** Three
**Source Text:** *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongxuan* Section, Jade Instructions Category

---

### **Preface to the Commentary on the *Scripture of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Chapters on Generating the Divine***

The *Jade Chapters on Generating the Divine* are how the Supreme Thearch proclaims the virtue of cherishing life. Thus, all methods of refining the sacred, blending the primordial, and ascending at dawn are fully encompassed within it. Yet its purport transcends the mundane, and its language is not of this world—without transmission and commentary, it is not easily understood.

I have heard that the Daoist of Mount Heng, Xue Youqi; the Supreme Clarity Attendant, Li Shaowei; and the Western Florescence Master, Cheng Xuanying—all transmitted teachings that penetrated the profound and investigated the subtle, though I have never seen their works. Later commentators were many, but only Wang Yinxian, Xiao Zhenyou, and the Perfected of Floating Mountain offered explanations that were particularly thorough. However, their interpretations sometimes differed, leaving readers unable to reconcile them and even leading to doubts.

For instance, regarding the cyclical renewal of the *jiashen* era, the matter is difficult to verify, yet some delve into obscure and recondite theories, startling the world and confounding custom—this is how such transmissions arise.

The divine is the numinous aspect of *qi*, riding the interplay of *yin* and *yang*, wielding transformation, circulating above and below, throughout the four directions, without obstruction. The heavens move through the four seasons, generating the myriad things. The divine person traverses great floods, reaching the heavens without drowning; treads upon scorched earth without burning; rides clouds and commands the wind—nothing can harm them. All this is the work of this divine *qi*.

For all people, when the divine *qi* gathers, life arises; when it scatters, death follows. The *Nine Chapters* take "generating the divine" as their title—its meaning is profound indeed.

Old commentaries number perhaps dozens, but the loftier ones verge on the abstruse, while the lesser ones cling to vulgar interpretations, leaving me sighing in regret. Recently, a visitor from Wu presented me with Hua Yangfu’s commentary. Upon examining its general intent, I found that it harmonizes the strengths of various interpretations, blending them into one. Drawing from the *Lingbao* and *Huangting* scriptures, it elucidates the Dao of cinnabar, making the profound simple and easily visible—like floating clouds clearing to reveal the bright moon hanging in the sky, leaving one with perfect clarity.

Ah! This commentary is a guide for those who study the Dao. How could its significance be merely about words? There must be superior scholars who diligently practice it, embodying what our Laozi spoke of.

Written on the fifth day after the Double Fifth Festival in the *renshen* year of the Zhishun era,
**Zhang Shouqing of Mount Wudang, the Perfected of Mysterious Response and Supreme Harmony, Founder of the Palace of Subtle Transformation in Supreme Clarity**

---

### **Commentary on the** *Scripture of the Natural Nine Heavens’ Chapters on Generating the Divine* **from the** *Dongxuan Lingbao*, **Volume One**
**Annotated by Hua Yangfu**

*Dong* means "void." *Xuan* means "profound and distant." Only the void can contain all wonders; only the profound and distant can give its meaning depth and endurance.

*Lingbao* ("Numinous Treasure") refers outwardly to the wondrous and weighty transformations of the sacred, and inwardly to the divine descending as the numinous and *qi* gathering as the treasure. Among the Three Treasures in the scripture, only *Lingbao* is singled out to mark the time when the book emerged to deliver humanity.

*Natural* refers to the original Three *Qi*, which appeared in response to the times, congealing in the great void. Phoenix scripts and dragon chapters took form without trace—naturally becoming patterns, not crafted by the intentional design of sages.

The *Nine Heavens* are the nine heavens from *Yushan Wu-liang* to *Wu-jie Wu-ai*. *Generating the divine* is the method of nurturing transformation and change.

A *scripture* is a book that carries the Dao, the path of cultivating the true.

---

### **The Golden Book of the Three Treasures in the Great Abundance**

The *Three Treasures* are the Heavenly Treasure, the Numinous Treasure, and the Divine Treasure. *Great Abundance* is the name of a heavenly palace. The *Scripture of Deliverance* states: "The Wondrous Court of Great Abundance"—speaking of the heavenly palace’s abundance, beyond which nothing can be added. This book was once secretly stored in this palace. Gold is the most precious and indestructible, hence its use here.

Its text comprises nine chapters, tracing their origins.

The *Heavenly Treasure Lord* is the revered deity of the *Great Cavern*. The *Heavenly Treasure Elder* is the ancestral *qi* of the Heavenly Treasure Lord. The Elder is the *qi* of the *Hundun Taiwu Yuan* and the *Supreme Void King*, numbering ninety-nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine billion *qi*. Later, in the first year of the *Longhan* era, the Heavenly Treasure Lord was born of transformation. At the time of the book’s emergence, he was titled *Supreme Great Abundance Jade Clarity Palace*.

The *Heavenly Treasure Lord* is the *Jade Clarity Primordial Beginning Heavenly Worthy*, originally congealed from the *qi* of the *Mystic Unity*. The highest is called *Heaven*; that which governs above is called *Thearch*. The Dao precedes the Thearch, hence it is called the *Primordial Beginning*. In the human body, it is the *Supreme Unity Emperor Lord*, the primordial spirit.

The *Great Cavern* is the origin of the teachings’ authority. *Elder* is a title of reverence, noble yet without rank. When the Heavenly Treasure Lord was born of transformation, the name was first established.

*Hundun Taiwu Yuan* refers to the form of the *Jade Void Heaven* before the primordial chaos was split. The number nine corresponds to the *yang* of *Qian*. The *Chart of Opening Transformation* states: "First is *Longhan*, second is *Yankang*, third is *Chiming*, fourth is *Shanghuang*, fifth is *Kaihuang*"—all names of past kalpas in the heavens. *Long* means "numinous," and *Han* means "heaven."

The *emergence of the book* refers to the *Scripture of Deliverance*’s five texts opening and expanding, universally planting the divine spirits. The *Jade Clarity Palace* is the abode of the Heavenly Treasure Lord’s mysterious seat. The *ancestral qi* is the Dao, and the Dao is the Heavenly Treasure Lord. Tracing its origins, the wondrous root is self-formed, with no ancestor above it. It takes emptiness and nothingness as its master, spontaneity as its foundation, enduring without governing, formless and nameless. When the sage establishes teachings, they cannot but honor its source, hence they force a name upon it as the ancestor of the Dao.

The *Numinous Treasure Lord* is the revered deity of the *Cavern Mystery*. The *Numinous Treasure Elder* is the ancestral *qi* of the Numinous Treasure Lord. The Elder is the *qi* of the *Chi-hun Taiwu Yuan* and the *Supreme Purple Void*, numbering ninety-nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine myriad *qi* of darkness. Later, at the opening of the *Longhan* chart, the Numinous Treasure Lord was born of transformation. After one kalpa, in the first year of the *Chiming* era, at the time of the book’s emergence to deliver humanity, he was titled *Supreme Clarity Mysterious Capital Jade Capital Seven Treasures Purple Tenuity Palace*.

*Purple Void* follows the Zhao edition.

The *Numinous Treasure Lord* is the *Celestial Worthy of Supreme Clarity*. From the One, the Two arises, becoming the *qi* of the *Primordial One*. "Numinous" signifies the wondrous and unfathomable. The *Cavern Mystery* scriptures and the *Numinous Treasure* teachings all emerge from the *Great Cavern*. According to the *Preface to the Collected Scriptures* in the *Canon*: the *Cavern Mystery* is the root, while the *Numinous Treasure* is its trace. The *qi* of the *Great Cavern* originally arises from emptiness, flowing into *Cavern Perfection*, then into *Cavern Mystery*, and further into *Cavern Spirit*. The preceding chapter refers to it not as *Cavern Perfection* but as the *Great Cavern*, speaking of its origin. *Chi-hun Taiwu Yuan* signifies that within the *Supreme Void*, the light and images have already begun to sprout, soon to manifest. From the *Longhan* chart’s opening, its traces were faintly revealed; by the *Chiming* era, when the scriptures emerged to deliver humanity, the civilizing influence first became radiant. *Chiming* and *Purple Void* describe the luminous and resplendent appearance of the *Cavern Yang*. "Delivering humanity" refers to the transmission of scriptural teachings, all of which are the Dao of rescuing beings from the cycle of birth and death. The *Purple Tenuity Palace* is where the *Numinous Treasure Lord* expounds the teachings and stores the scriptures. Compared to the *Jade Void*, its *qi* is diminished by nine hundred million myriad, thus one knows that as kalpas descend and epochs shift, it scatters into the ten thousand existences, no longer resembling the primordial undifferentiated state.

The sage’s intent in revealing these scriptures was to fear that later ages would grow shallow and frivolous, pursuing superficialities, deceit, and cunning, cutting short their Heaven-bestowed years, drifting endlessly in the sea of suffering. Thus, he wished to return them to purity and restore their roots, valuing *qi* and securing their foundation to advance the immortal Dao. Therefore, he revealed the divine chapters, earnestly admonishing and awakening them—no virtue could be greater.

The *Spirit Treasure Lord* is the revered deity of the *Cavern Spirit*. The *Spirit Treasure Elder* is the ancestral *qi* of the *Spirit Treasure Lord*. The Elder is the *qi* of *Mysterious Tranquility, Profound Communication, Primordial Non-Being, and Supreme Clarity Void*, numbering ninety-nine thousand nine hundred ninety million *qi*. Later, in the first year of the *Chiming* era, the *Spirit Treasure Lord* was born of transformation. After two kalpas, in the first year of the *Shanghuang* era, when the scriptures emerged, he was titled *Three Sovereigns’ Cavern Spirit Supreme Clarity Great Ultimate Palace of Pure Void*, following the Zhao edition.

The *Spirit Treasure Lord* is the *Celestial Worthy of Supreme Purity*. From the Two, the Three arises, becoming the *qi* of the *Primal One*. "Spirit" is the name for the unfathomable transformations of yin and yang. The *Cavern Spirit* teachings expound the Dao of *Supreme Clarity*’s *Great Peace* and *non-action*. Its revered scriptures comprise twelve sections, with additional texts such as the *Purple Void Register*, *Disaster Dispelling and Calamity Averting*, and *Pure Tranquility Heavenly Youth*, all belonging to this tradition. *Mysterious Tranquility, Profound Communication, Primordial [Non-Being]* describe a state of thoughtless non-action, serene and unmoving, yet responsive when stimulated. The original text lacked the character *Primordial*; Wang Yinxian later added it to complete the *Three Primordials*. *Pure Void* refers to the light and clarity of Heaven. Compared to *Chi-hun*, its *qi* is further diminished by ninety myriad, growing ever more attenuated with descent. The *Great Ultimate Palace* is the immortal realm of *Supreme Clarity*. All immortals who attain the Dao, observe the precepts, and present petitions gather here to pay homage. Within the palace, the officials, perfected ones, and immortal ministers stand in solemn order.

Within the *Great Cavern* teachings, there are the *Three Primordial Palaces*. The *Celestial Worthy* once commanded Generals Tang, Ge, and Zhou to guard and purify the palace gates. These deities correspond above to the *Three Qi* and below to the three regions of the human body. In Heaven, they assist the pivotal mechanisms of the Northern Dipper and govern talismans, sacred writings, covenants, and registers. When one’s cultivation of the *Great Cavern*’s practices is complete, these three deities guide one’s ascension to pay homage at the imperial palace—this is the Dao of primordial unity.

During the *Zhihe* era of the Song dynasty, Emperor Renzong fell ill and dreamed he wandered through thorns, lost and bewildered. He saw a divine figure clad in golden armor, who said to him: "Heaven grants Your Majesty twelve more years of life for your benevolent heart." The emperor asked, "By what path may I return?" The divine figure replied, "I shall send you with my chariot." The emperor mounted the chariot and inquired who the deity was. The reply came: "Your subject is General Ge." Upon awakening, the emperor recovered and ordered the *Daoist Canon* to be searched. Indeed, General Ge was recorded as presiding over the Heavenly Gate. The emperor then elevated his rank and established a temple for him in the capital. It is regrettable that at the time, no one memorialized this deity, who corresponds to the *qi* of one’s own body, to enhance the practice of nurturing life.

Though these three titles differ in name and era, their essence is one. They divide into the *Primordial*, *Mysterious*, and *Initial* *Three Qi* to govern. The *Three Treasures* are the revered deities of the *Three Qi*, giving rise to the *Three Qi*, and the three titles together generate the *Nine Qi*. The *Nine Qi* emerge before the *Great Void*, concealed within the empty cavern, without light or image, form or name, color or trace, sound or voice.

The three titles correspond to the *Three Clarities*’ palaces. The "eras" refer to the five kalpas of transformation. Though their names differ, their principle is one. From the *Mysterious One*’s *qi*, the *Heavenly Treasure* was born; later, it divided into the *Primordial One* and *Initial One* *qi*, becoming the *Numinous Treasure* and *Spirit Treasure*. Once the *Three Qi* are complete, they generate the *Nine Qi*, and the *Nine Qi* scatter into the ten thousand *qi* to establish the roots of living beings.

Before the *Nine Qi* emerged, their light was submerged and their traces obscured, merging indistinguishably into one—beyond governance or inquiry. Guiding the cosmos and governing the world, they opened the mysterious and interconnected, the three hues of chaos flickering in and out of existence. As the revolutions of destiny reached their limit, the *Three Qi* radiated light. The *qi* clarified and ascended, accumulating into yang to form Heaven; the *qi* congealed and settled, accumulating into stagnation to form Earth. The *Nine Qi* arrayed in order, giving rise to the sun, moon, stars, the five agents, yin and yang, and all people and creatures—all receiving life and completion.

From the One dividing into Three comes the *Spirit Treasure Lord*, who governs the *qi* of *Mysterious Tranquility, Profound Communication, and Primordial Non-Being*, guiding yin and yang to accomplish the work of transformation and overseeing the life and death of the world’s people. The *three hues* are the *Mysterious Qi* (azure), the *Primordial Qi* (yellow), and the *Initial Qi* (white). Before the *Three Qi* divided, they flickered between existence and non-existence, their mechanisms already foreshadowed, soon to emerge with the turning of destiny. After their division, Heaven and Earth were established in their positions, and people and creatures arose accordingly—here one sees that Heaven, Earth, and humanity all emerge from the Dao.

The myriad transformations of Heaven and Earth, without the nurturing of the *Three Primordials* or the guidance of the *Nine Qi*, could not come into being. The *Three Qi* are the lords of Heaven and Earth, the *Nine Qi* are the roots of the ten thousand things. Thus, the union of the Three completes virtue—this is the ultimate of Heaven and Earth.

The *Three Primordials* and *Three Qi* are the ancestors of Heaven and Earth, hence their revered status. They transform and give rise to the *Nine Qi*, which govern the movements of yin and yang and nurture the ten thousand kinds—thus they are called the roots. The *Threefold Union* refers to the congealing and merging of the *Three Qi*, whose transformations are boundless, and from which the virtue of generation and completion arises. The meaning of *ultimate* aligns with the *Great Ultimate*, the convergence and pivot of yin-yang and the Five Phases.

When a person receives life within the womb, the *Three Primordials* nurture and sustain, while the *Nine Qi* shape the form. Thus, after nine months, the spirits are arrayed, the qi is full, and the voice emerges. With the voice, the spirit is complete, and the Nine Heavens rejoice. The *Grand Unity* holds the talisman, the *Imperial Lord* ranks and commands, the *Director of Destinies* records and inscribes, the *Life-Span Decreer* fixes the allotment, the *Five Emperors* oversee birth, the *Holy Mother* guards the chamber, and the deities of Heaven and Earth, along with the guardians of the Three Realms, all stand vigil. The *Marshal of the Nine Heavens* stands in the courtyard, facing east, and recites the *Ninefold Treasured Scripture of the Birth of Spirits* nine times. If the child is male, the myriad spirits chant in reverence; if female, they chant in devotion. If male, the *Director of Destinies* responds with respect; if female, with compliance. Only then is the child born. If the *Marshal of the Nine Heavens* does not issue the *Mandate Scripture*, and the myriad spirits do not chant their reverent responses, birth cannot occur.

Humans are the most spiritually endowed of all beings, endowed with the harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth. Before birth, they dwell in profound obscurity, and only through transformation do they enter the mother’s womb to become human. The *Three Primordials* distribute qi to form the *Three Fields*, which govern the entire body. The qi of the Nine Heavens sequentially coalesce to form the hun and po souls, the five viscera, and the hundred bones, giving rise to the complete person. By the time nine months—two hundred seventy days—have passed, the *three nines* are complete, and the child separates from the mother’s form. At this moment, voice, form, spirit, and qi are all perfected, and the work of the *Birth of Spirits* in the Nine Heavens is finally accomplished. How could this not be cause for celebration?

According to the *Mysterious Mirror*, the *Grand Unity* is the great master of long life, the *Great Unity* of the *Supreme Clarity* and *Great Cavern*, who holds the talisman to unite the hundred spirits. The *Imperial Lord* is the *Lord of the Myriad Spirits*, who determines rank and status. The *Director of Destinies* is the *Central Elder*, named *Li Mingchu*, styled *Xuandu Qing*. The *Life-Span Decreer* predetermines longevity or early death. The *Five Emperors* are the lords of the Five Phases, who bestow the true qi of the Five Phases upon the body. The *Holy Mother* is the *Holy Mother of the Nine Heavens*, the supreme yin ruler, who delights in the completion of beings and thus wards off inauspicious influences. The *Marshal of the Nine Heavens* is entrusted with guarding the jade scriptures and, facing east, recites the scriptures to invoke the qi of generation. The myriad spirits chanting reverence or devotion, like the presentation of jade scepters or tiles to distinguish male and female, are as such. If the *Marshal* does not issue the *Mandate Scripture*, then the Mandate of Heaven is not bestowed. If the myriad spirits do not chant their reverent responses, then the Principle of Heaven does not flow. How, then, could birth occur?

That a person comes to life is by no means easily obtained. Should one not strive to advance in the virtuous Way to preserve what Heaven has bestowed? The *True Master of Mount Float* said: When a person does good, the yang spirits rejoice, saying, “Today we celebrate, for this person aligns with Heaven.” If one does evil, the spirits mourn, saying, “We have lost the mandate previously bestowed upon this person, and together we shall fall into the dark yin.” Su Dongpo’s poem to Chen Lüchang on *Refraining from Killing* reads: “Have you not seen Wang Wuzi? Before his death, the spirits already wept.” This expresses the same sentiment.

The *Mandate Scripture* is what Heaven bestows as destiny, as the *Book of Documents* says: “Only the August Lord-on-High bestows the centeredness upon the people below.” The *Doctrine of the Mean* states: “What Heaven imparts is called *nature*.” Though Heaven does not speak, it entrusts the work of creation to the jade scriptures, hence the term *Mandate Scripture*. For a person to return and be born into the human realm, to bathe in the form of the Great Yang, is an event so momentous it startles Heaven and Earth—its value is beyond measure. The true spirits of Heaven and Earth, along with the deities of the Three Realms, all attend, for this is no trivial matter. Even at the moment of birth, it is not to be considered insignificant. Therefore, one should cherish one’s form, preserve one’s spirit, honor one’s qi, and secure one’s roots, so as never to die or decay, and thus attain immortality. With flesh and bones ascending together, one mounts to the *Three Clarities*, aligning virtue with the *Three Qi* and uniting with the *Nine Qi*. Yet, though born human, one may fail to revere one’s qi, honor one’s form, treasure one’s life, or cherish one’s spirit, thereby bringing about death and decay, and severing oneself from one’s original true nature.

Humans experience life and death, but nature itself knows no life or death. Those who transcend life and death have surely heard the Dao or perceived their nature. Ordinary people, their habitual tendencies unremoved, are bound by karma, lingering in the dark yin, or locked in mutual retribution. Once the karmic debt is exhausted and the virtuous nature remains unperished, they may return to the human realm, but only after bathing in the Great Yang do they enter the womb. Above the sun lies a dwelling called the *Palace of Cavern Yang*, a pool of flowing fire containing the *True Water of Yellow Blossoms*. The divine beings there use this water to bathe their bodies. The *Documents of Long Life* speak of the *Yellow Blossom Washing the Form*—this is what it refers to. From attaining human birth, through so many stages, startling Heaven and Earth—how could this be considered trivial? If one can refine and nurture the original spirit, return to the root and restore purity, merging with the *Three Qi* and *Nine Qi*, then the principle of ascending with flesh and bones to the *Three Clarities* is within reach. Yet, failing to exert oneself and thus falling into death and decay—how lamentable!

In the past, Minister Ouyang Wenzhong, though he did not pursue the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi throughout his life, in his later years, while guarding the Bo She, suddenly gained insight. One day, he sought the Dao from the hermit Shi Tang. The hermit replied: “Your dwelling is already in ruins; it is difficult to speak of such matters now. If you can only clarify your past circumstances, there may yet be hope.” Though Minister Ouyang’s literary and official achievements crowned his generation, did he lack the capacity to receive the Dao? He merely missed the opportunity too late. Nevertheless, the work of attaining the Dao lies in awakening the nature, and one must cultivate the foundation of life as the root. If one cannot revere qi, honor form, preserve life, or cherish spirit, and thus allows decline to set in, with mercury dried and lead exhausted, the foundation of life eroded and the true nature obscured—then, to undertake cultivation at such a time is like digging a well when thirsty. Is it not too late?

The *Nine Heavens’ Chapter of Generating Spirits* is the resonant sound formed by the triune fusion of the *qi* of the Three Caverns’ Flying Mystery, a sacred text that coalesces the hundred spirits, concealing their inner names within its hidden rhythm. It is the natural scripture through which *qi* generates form. The *Flying Mystery* refers to the primordial *qi* of the Originator soaring through the Great Void, merging the Three Caverns into written revelation, its tones harmonizing like metal and stone, gathering the ceaseless creative intent of Heaven and Earth. Within it lie the inner names of the hundred spirits; when recited, the spirits hear their names called and assemble to commune with the divine.

The *Jade Pivot Scripture* states:
*"The nine numina within the body—why not summon them? To summon them is auspicious.
The three essences within the body—why not invoke them? To invoke them is blessed."*

Reciting it as the *Heavenly Treasure* opens the radiance of Heaven and Earth.
Reciting it as the *Numinous Treasure* awakens the souls of the Nine Dark Realms from eternal night.
Reciting it as the *Spiritual Treasure* commands the ten thousand spirits.
Reciting it as the *Grand Unity* equips the body’s gods.
Reciting it as the *Imperial Lord* shapes the form.
Reciting it as the *Nine Heavens* generates humanity.
Reciting it as the *Learned Adept* ascends to Heaven.

When the Lords of the Three Treasures recite the Jade Chapter, they proclaim the wonders of the Dao. The *Grand Unity* is the Primordial Lady of the Grand Unity; the *Imperial Lord* is the Sovereign Lord of the Grand Unity. Though the Jade Chapter is one, those who recite it differ, and according to their virtue and power, the transformations and responses they evoke vary in depth.

When ghostly spirits hear it, they ascend and advance.
When ordinary mortals hear it, they endure and abide.
When imprisoned souls hear it, they are liberated and delivered.
When withered husks hear it, they emit smoke and revive.
When infants hear it, they gain speech.
When dead remains hear it, they return to life.

The *ghostly spirits* are ghostly officials. The *Flying Immortal’s Sword Scripture* records that Xiao Miao, a man of talent and renown, became a stalwart ghost and served four hundred years before ascending to rule the underworld. Now, upon hearing this scripture, he need not wait for his term to end, for he may hope for promotion and advancement.

The *ordinary mortals* are those possessed of the six desires; through the scripture, they attain purity and stillness, and thus may endure in the world. The *imprisoned souls* are ghosts confined in the hells of darkness; upon hearing the scripture, they are fortunate to be liberated, as was Zhang Lihua, who entreated the recitation of the Jade Chapter for deliverance.

The *withered husks* are rotting wood and dead grass. *Emitting smoke* signifies the revival of primordial *qi*. The Reverted Immortal of Yueyang City’s south used cinnabar to restore an ancient tree—this is the same principle. When *infants gain speech*, their orifices open and their faculties sharpen. When *dead remains return to life*, it is as when Xu Jia, reduced to dry bones, was revived by the Lord Lao with the *Great Mystery’s Life Talisman*—this is the same truth.

The Three Treasures’ divine mysteries are the root of all myriad beings. Thus, they are beyond the ken of ghosts and spirits, beyond what ordinary mortals may hear.

The Jade Chapter is prized by the Three Eminent Lords; its efficacy serves as the root of all myriad beings’ generation. Tracing its profound principles, even spirits and gods, though numinous, cannot fathom them—how much less can ordinary mortals?

Those who study the supreme Dao aspire to transcendence as immortals. Upon attaining *corpse liberation*, they escape the cycle of rebirth and dissolution, ultimately returning to the immortal Dao, where form and spirit unite, never parting, both entering the true reality of the Way. Without this scripture, however, the womb’s obstructions congeal, the *qi* of death solidifies the root of life, the true radiance cannot be preserved, the *qi* of generation lacks sustenance, the nine orifices remain blocked, the body fails to engender spirit, and one merely receives a single form, as if borrowing *qi* to animate it. Those who master this method may sit and attain spontaneity.

The Way of the Supreme Perfected comprises seven paths; the Way of the Most High, three; the Way of the Middle Perfected, six; and the Way of the Lesser Perfected, eight. This chapter shares its meaning with the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Scripture*. Those who study transcendence, their strength shallow and their steps halting, have yet to escape the Three Realms and can only achieve *corpse liberation*. Though they have not yet escaped the cycle of rebirth and dissolution, they ultimately return to the immortal Dao. For those who cherish their form and preserve their spirit, they draw near to the Way.

The *True Records* state that when one dies as if still living—feet uncyanosed, skin unwrinkled, eyes as bright as in life—this is *corpse liberation*. Without this scripture, one cannot obtain the essential method of the Jade Chapter and the Great Cavern, nor sever the obstructions of the womb. Thus, they fear the *qi* of death will solidify their life’s root, and the true radiance cannot be long preserved. The *true radiance* is the light of spirit. Though they attain *corpse liberation*, they merely receive a single form, as if borrowing *qi* to animate the body—a withered tree briefly revived in spring, its fluids unsustained, unable to endure.

Those who obtain this method master the secret of harmonizing the hundred spirits. Generally, the human body is born of the Three *Qi*. Having received this illumination, one becomes one with the Primordial Beginning, able to blend with the *qi* of the mundane, the spirit following wherever it resides. Initially, the Three *Qi* generate the Three Spirits, which divide into the Three Sections, Eight Radiant Ones, and Twenty-Four Spirits. If one can harmonize and transform them, the Three and Five Perfected Ones coalesce into the Orthodox Unity, enabling one to summon yang and invoke yin, moving without constraint. Yang *qi* transforms into dragons and simurghs; yin *qi* into jade maidens. Riding the whirlwind chariot beyond the Eight Extremities, one sits and attains spontaneity—how could this be deceit?

The Three Treasures are revered; the Perfected Ones of the Nine Heavens are most sacred. Their secrets are vast, sealed within the Ninefold Golden Racks of the Purple Yang Jade Terrace. Unless heaven and earth are newly opened, this scripture will not emerge. It is the *Forbidden Book of the Primordial Beginning*, beyond the ken of ghosts and spirits. Whoever steals it will be severed by the wind-blade for ten thousand kalpas, their soul perishing without rebirth. Those who follow the precepts and revere it will unite form and spirit in transcendence.

According to the *Seven Transformations That Harm Heaven Scripture*, the Three Hundred Scrolls of the Supreme Clarity’s sacred scriptures, the Seven Thousand Jade Instructions, the Seven Thousand Talismans, and the Spontaneous Chapters are all concealed in the Palace of Great Existence above the Nine Heavens—this is one such text. The Ninefold Golden Racks and Purple Yang Jade Terrace are where the scriptures are stored. *Ninefold* signifies layer upon layer, like treasures wrapped in tenfold silk. *Racks* refer to shelves for books. The *Scripture of the Dao-Treasure* speaks of jade and golden racks, so strictly guarded that even spirits dare not steal a glance. Only when heaven and earth are illuminated and the mystic wind flows freely do the true scriptures and sacred talismans descend in due time. Those who revere them long enough will surely attain enlightenment, rightfully uniting form and spirit in transcendence.

The Three Primordial Palaces hold golden names inscribed in purple characters, marking those destined to become Perfected Ones of the Three Clarities in their next lives. They are fit to receive this scripture. When the karmic conditions align, they should offer gold and treasures, serve their masters with devotion, and receive the precepts through ritual covenant. They must guard their hearts and practice diligently, never lightly disclosing it, lest the wind-blade examine their bodies.

The Three Primordials’ judgment extends not only to the dead but to all—whether they have attained the Way or not. Only those with golden names and purple characters are distinguished as students of transcendence. The scriptures speak of the Three Primordials’ judgment halls in the underworld, called the *Ink Registers*—the black ledgers. The difference between those with golden names and purple characters and others is as vast as heaven and earth.

In former times, Li Jue, a commoner of Jiangyang, had long accumulated merit in the immortal registers. Though he had not yet ascended, his name was already inscribed in gold by the immortal officials in the Huayang Grotto-Heaven. This distinction is not exclusive to immortals. When Emperor Yuan of Liang was Prince of Xiangdong, he recorded loyal ministers, righteous scholars, and those of literary excellence, using three kinds of brushes: gold-tipped for the loyal and filial, silver-tipped for those of virtuous conduct, and mottled bamboo for those of fine writing. Such distinctions exist even among mortals.

This refers to those with prior karmic ties to transcendence, whose names are recorded in the immortal registers. Only they may receive and uphold the Jade Chapter, offering gold and treasures to their masters with sincerity, never transmitting it lightly. *Guarding the heart and practicing diligently* means calming the mind, dispelling distractions, and steadfastly following the scriptural teachings. Those who leak or disdain it bring calamity upon themselves.

The method of cultivation requires a thousand-day retreat, disengaging from worldly affairs and exhausting all sensory leaks. One pacifies the mind, silently recites, burns pure incense, and observes the precepts. Entering the chamber facing east, one knocks the teeth nine times, regulates the voice and aligns the *qi*, then chants the sacred chapter. *Retreat* means single-minded emptiness. The method of cultivation aims for completion in three years.

Before the retreat, the heart contends with external things, racing like wind and blazing like fire, never resting. Once in retreat, one unifies thoughts, attaining profound stillness, becoming one with the Great Void. The scriptures speak of the *Eight Leaks*: tears from the eyes (liver leak), nasal mucus (lung leak), saliva (kidney leak), sweat (heart leak), night sweats (small intestine leak), drool during sleep (brain leak), dreams of intercourse with spirits (spirit leak), and lustful desires (body leak). When the heart, the sovereign, is settled, all these cease. *Pacifying* means leveling; *silent recitation* means contemplating the Supreme Perfected.

Once, Master Ge the Immortal observed a prolonged retreat on Mount Tiantai. Before even a year had passed, his devotion moved the Supreme Perfected, who deigned to glance into his secluded chamber—this was the response to his prolonged retreat. Entering the chamber facing east, he aligned with the qi of generation. He struck his teeth: the left as the *Celestial Bell*, to subdue demonic spirits; the right as the *Celestial Chime*, to gather the hundred spirits; and the center as the *Celestial Drum*, to summon the Perfected Sages. Striking the teeth, burning incense, modulating the voice, and rectifying the qi—all are essential methods for reciting scriptures.

Reciting once, the sound reaches the Nine Heavens.
Reciting twice, Heaven and Earth display reverence.
Reciting thrice, the Three Realms bow to the chamber.
Reciting four times, Heavenly Kings descend as immortals.
Reciting five times, the Five Emperors pay homage to the Perfected.
Reciting six times, demon kings bind themselves.
Reciting seven times, the stellar lodges halt their gates.
Reciting eight times, the darkest night becomes luminous.
Reciting nine times, all heavens descend in attendance, and every spirit and numinous being, without exception, guards the carriage.

This chapter unites the marvel of Heaven and humanity as one. There is no duality between Heaven and humanity. My heart is the heart of Heaven and Earth; my qi is the qi of Heaven and Earth. Having embraced singular sincerity, this resonance elicits that response. "Once" means reciting a chapter through once, its sound reaching the Nine Heavens. Formerly, Duke Jing of Song uttered a single word, and Mars retreated from its station. Tang, reproaching himself for six faults, brought rain across thousands of miles. If such is the resonance of their responses, how much more so the chanting of the ancestral qi’s tone?

For the transformation of ancestral qi is vast, encompassing Heaven and Earth, pervading the Three Realms, stellar lodges, and Five Phases. Externally, it extends to demon kings; below, to the shades of the dark. All spirits and numinous beings derive from this source, flowing and spreading in accordance with their stations, thus giving rise to distinctions of good and evil, high and low.

Twice: the gods of Heaven and Earth hear it and display reverence.
Thrice: the deities of the Three Realms descend to bow before the chamber of scripture recitation.
Four times: Heavenly Kings descend as immortals. Among Daoist heavenly deities, there are titles such as *Dharma King* and *Heavenly King*. Through invocation, they descend—just as Master Ge’s refined devotion in retreat summoned the descent of Perfected Xu to transmit scriptures.
Five times: the Five Emperors, lords of the Five Qi, behold the true scripture’s abode and pay homage.
Six times: the Yin-numbered demon kings, the great demons of the Six Heavens, who share in the Primordial Beginning’s dissemination. In retreat and jiao rites, there is a method to command demons, driving them away so that upon hearing the scriptures, they bind themselves and dare not intrude.
Seven times: the stellar lodges halt their gates, as in the *Scripture of Salvation*, where the *Celestial Pivot* ceases its turning, and divine radiance attains great stillness.
Eight times: the darkest night reveals light, as Yang breaks through Yin.
Nine times: all heavens descend in attendance, and spirits guard the carriage. As when Li Shun chanted the *Great Cavern Scripture* for three years, one evening thousands of flying immortals suddenly gathered in the sky, their divine radiance illuminating his chamber, and he attained the Dao. The merit and virtue thus evoked are like a corpse dwelling yet a dragon appearing, like profound silence yet thunderous sound—unexpected yet inevitable.

Once through reaches Heaven, the *bao yuan* opens and flows.
The preceding speaks of external resonance; this speaks of internal achievement, elucidating the method of the Great Cavern and returning elixir. "Once through opens the *bao yuan*" refers to Heaven generating Water. Human life begins in the *bao yuan*, where the qi of coagulating embryo and yellow essence circulates, ascending and descending without losing its measure, thus gradually nurturing vitality. If the *bao yuan* remains obstructed, there will surely be the affliction of heavenly blockage. For those cultivating the true, when first applying effort to the inner elixir, thoughts, intentions, qi, and breath all settle, spirit and essence begin to gather, and the lower gate of the *Mingmen* opens from this point.

Twice through resounds in Earth, the root of the fetal knot dissolves.
Earth generates Fire, and in the second month, the fetus forms. Yet the dead qi’s old root may cause it to bind and solidify, so it must be steamed and dispersed by true qi to enable growth. The *Supreme Clarity Cavern Mystery Scripture* contains the talisman of the Great One Emperor Lord for dissolving the Three Passes and Twelve Knots, written in red on green bamboo membrane and recited to dissolve them.

Thrice through, spirits bow, the *hun* gate refines the immortal.
Heaven generates Wood, which in humans becomes the *hun*. In the third month, Yin and Yang begin to separate, and the *hun* acquires form. The *hun* gate lies to the left, belonging to Yang. In the third revolution of elixir refinement, Yang qi becomes sufficient. The method involves concentrating spirit and entering breath to nurture it, whereby divine intelligence naturally arises, the Azure Emperor guards the *hun*, and the Lord of Wood records the tally.

Four times through, Heavenly Kings descend as immortals, the *po* gate closes its barrier.
Earth generates Metal, which in humans becomes the *po*. In the fourth month, the *po* is born. The *po* gate lies to the right, belonging to Yin. In the fourth revolution of elixir refinement, Yang nurtures Yin, causing the *po* to be carried by the *hun*. The method takes the nose as the heavenly aperture, connecting to the lungs. The lungs govern the *po*; when profoundly still, the breath of coming and going ceases—this is called closing the barrier. Naturally, the *Flowery Pond* fills with water, descending to irrigate the heart’s network. Heart Fire descends, Kidney Water ascends, *ding* and *ren* unite, and the inner elixir harmonizes. If the barrier is not closed, the *hun* scatters and wanders, following dreams in and out. Unable to restrain it, the *po* acts at will, and one ultimately joins the ranks of ghosts.

Five times through, the Five Emperors pay homage to the Perfected, the viscera and bowels become clear and cool.
Heaven generates Earth; in the fifth month of human life, the Five Phases’ qi is complete, generating the five viscera and six bowels. The five viscera are the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys. The six bowels are the small intestine, gallbladder, stomach, large intestine, bladder, and Triple Burner. "Clear and cool" means tranquil and undisturbed. Those cultivating the true abstain from desire, so the kidneys do not leak essence; they practice stillness, so the heart does not lose spirit; they stabilize breath, so the lungs can pacify the *po*; they simplify vision, so the liver can nurture the *hun*; and they concentrate thought, so the spleen can settle intention. With the Yellow Center penetrating principle, preserving the Great Harmony, spirit, essence, *hun*, *po*, and intention gather into one—this is called assembling the Five Phases. Their qi ascends to pay homage to the *Mud Pill*, which is called paying homage to the Perfected. Then the Azure Emperor guards the *hun*, the White Emperor attends the *po*, the Red Emperor nurtures qi, the Black Emperor circulates blood, and the Yellow Emperor presides at the center—ten thousand spirits do not transgress.

The Six Perils’ demon-kings submit in compliance, and the stomach’s tube generates fluid. The demon-kings refer to the inner promptings of the six desires. *Nuo* means submission. Restrained by the jade scripture, they submit and yield. The stomach and spleen form an outer-inner pair, storing water and grain to nourish the five viscera. The *Classic of Difficulties* states that the qi of the five viscera all converge in the stomach. Moreover, the moistening of fluids depends on thought. If one is enticed by the six desires, thought loses its correctness, and one sees food as drool, encounters sorrow as tears, shame as sweat, anger as surging blood—all flowing away without return. Internally deprived of nourishment, essence, qi, and spirit scatter and leak, leaving only a withered husk, which is the cohort of death. If the six demon-kings submit in compliance, thought regains its correctness, governed within, then fluid arises in the stomach’s cavity, irrigating the four limbs, flowing to moisten the elixir crucible. Essence, qi, and spirit thereby congeal and unite—this is the cohort of life.

The Seven Perils’ stellar lodges shine bright, and the orifices open with keen perception. Heaven has the seven luminaries; humans have the seven orifices. By the seventh month, all are open to govern seeing, hearing, eating, breathing, and intake and output. Some say that keen perception originally arises from the heart, corresponding to the number of fire. The supremely wise have seven apertures in the heart, hence their keen perception. The dull have few or none, hence their dullness and turbidity. With seven revolutions of the elixir practice, the heavy barriers dissolve, and clarity pervades above and below. The *Heart Seal Scripture* states: “The seven orifices interpenetrate, each orifice radiant with light. The sagely sun and sagely moon illuminate the golden court.”

The Eight Perils’ dark night reveals light, and the three divisions’ eight luminous spirits fully integrate form and spirit. Yanluozi said: “In the eighth month, the spirits are complete.” The three divisions are the upper, middle, and lower. The *Central Alliance Register* records: the upper division’s eight luminous spirits are the spirit of hair, brain, eyes, nose, ears, mouth, tongue, and teeth. The middle division’s eight luminous spirits are the spirits of the lungs, heart, liver, spleen, left kidney, right kidney, gallbladder, and throat. The lower division has eight luminous spirits: the spirits of the stomach, large intestine, small intestine, navel, chest diaphragm, two flanks, left yin and left yang, and right yin and right yang. Together they number twenty-four, corresponding to the twenty-four qi. The upper division’s spirits take the brain spirit as their origin, stored at dawn. The middle division’s spirits take the heart spirit as their master, stored at noon. The lower division’s spirits take the kidney spirit as their master, stored at midnight. When the work of the Eight Perils nears completion, the body naturally emits light, illuminating the hidden and manifest. The three divisions’ eight luminous spirits are all fully integrated without laziness. The *Scripture of Salvation* states: “The eight luminous spirits darkly merge, and qi enters the profound mystery.”

The Nine Perils: all heavens descend in visitation. The three barriers, five viscera, six bowels, nine palaces, golden tower and jade chamber, twelve layered gates, purple portals and jade enclosures—thirty-six thousand joints, their roots and origins, all simultaneously generate spirit. The *Yellow Court* takes the mouth as the Heavenly Barrier, the hands as the Human Barrier, and the feet as the Earthly Barrier. Also, below the brain is the Upper Barrier, beside the spine is the Middle Barrier, and the kidneys facing each other form the Lower Barrier. The viscera and bowels were noted earlier. The *Nine Palaces Cavern-Truth Scripture* states: “Three *fen* within the space between the eyebrows is the Double Cinnabar Palace; one *cun* inward is the Hall of Light Palace; three *cun* inward is the Cinnabar Field Palace, also called the Mud Pill Palace; four *cun* is the Flowing Pearl Palace; five *cun* is the Emperor’s Palace. One *cun* above the Hall of Light is the Heavenly Court Palace; one *cun* above the Cavern Chamber is the Ultimate Truth Palace; one *cun* above the Cinnabar Field is the Mysterious Cinnabar Palace; one *cun* above the Flowing Pearl is the Supreme Sovereign Palace.” The golden tower is the throat, also called the layered tower, within which twelve wardens hold jade halberds to guard it, governing the circulation of qi above and below. The *Yellow Court Scripture* says: “Within the layered tower are twelve rings; from high to low, all are perfected beings.” The jade chamber is another name for the brain palace. The *Yellow Court* calls it the jasper chamber. The purple portals, according to the *Plain Questions and Spiritual Pivot Middle Section*, lie within the space above the eyebrows, where the Purple Chamber Cavern resides, guarded externally by the myriad spirits’ sovereign, named Feng Lingfan. The jade enclosure is the Jade Hall, namely the lower cinnabar field. There are eighteen thousand yang spirits and eighteen thousand yin spirits, totaling thirty-six thousand. This describes how, in the womb, the embryo’s form and qi transform, and by the ninth month, all spirits within the body simultaneously arise. With nine revolutions of the elixir practice, the sagely embryo is complete, and the myriad qi ascend as immortals—it is likewise so. The Nine Perils complete one cycle. When one cycle concludes, the Three Realms record one’s name, the Five Emperors befriend and distinguish one, and one is called a Perfected. Ten cycles unify qi, controlling and commanding the myriad spirits. Demon-kings protect and recommend one, and one is listed among the heavens. A hundred cycles unify spirit, attaining spontaneity. The Great One’s tally is received, and the Primordial Lord grants life. A thousand cycles unify numen, enabling one to sit or stand at will, vanish or appear. Immortal youths and jade maidens serve at one’s command. Ten thousand cycles complete the Dao, enabling one to ride a dragon chariot and ascend in broad daylight. The Three Realms record one’s name, and heaven and humanity praise one’s virtue. The Five Emperors are the lords of the five directions and five qi. *You bie* means recording one’s meritorious deeds, regarding one as a friend, and distinguishing one from ordinary people. Refining the body into qi is called a Perfected. “Ten cycles unify qi” means the Dao’s qi circulates, and ghosts and spirits submit. Demon-kings protect and recommend one: when one first cultivates the Dao, demon-kings test one; if one does not retreat, they protect and recommend one, inscribing one’s name in the heavenly register, and only then does one attain the Dao. “Unifying spirit” means transformation without limit, attaining spontaneity without relying on thought or action—such as summoning the Six Jias’ traveling kitchen. The Great One’s tally: the Great One is the lord of a hundred spirits; the tally symbolizes the numinous qi within the body. The *Scripture of Salvation* states: “Holding the register and grasping the tally, preserving life and planting the root.”

The Yuanjun is the title of a female immortal, the mother of the qi within the human body. The *Daode Jing* states: “Alone I differ from others, valuing the seeking of sustenance from the mother.” A thousand cycles unify the numinous: when the practice is pure and refined, its wondrous applications are unfathomable, and one may sit in presence or vanish while standing.

The jade lads and maidens who are dispatched east and west practice the method of guarding the Three Ones. The *Shangqing Mingtang Xuandan Zhenjing* states: “If a Daoist cultivates the Supreme Lord’s method of summoning the Three Ones to guard the form, they may meet with Perfected Ones, attain communion with the numinous and penetrating vision, sit in presence or vanish while standing, and command the Six Dings. The Celestial Emperor grants twelve jade lads and twelve jade maidens to attend at their left and right.”

Upon reaching ten thousand cycles, this heart merges entirely with the scripture as one, enabling one to ride clouds and drive dragons, roaming and feasting in the Grand Clarity.

"Ascending the dawn" refers to rising and ascending with the clarity of the dawn qi, visualizing the Great One in harmonious union—this time is often employed for such practices. The *Huangting Jing* says: “With feathered robes arrayed, the Eight Winds are driven; controlling the reins of the Three Primes, one ascends the rosy dawn.”

*Commentary on the* Wondrous Scripture of the Natural Nine Heavens’ Spontaneous Generation of Spirit *concludes, Volume the Upper.*

*Commentary on the* Wondrous Scripture of the Natural Nine Heavens’ Spontaneous Generation of Spirit, *Volume the Middle.*

Within the Yellow Chamber of the Cloud Palace, the Primordial Celestial Worthy of Original Commencement reposed in tranquil seclusion, reclining amidst the seven-jeweled curtains, nurturing purity and refining the true, savoring the penetrating wisdom and delving into the subtle principles of spirit-generation, where the profoundest mysteries merge with the Great Primordial—his resonant whistling echoing through the Nine Heavens.

The Celestial Worthy’s repose and refinement of the true in stillness bespoke a natural ease, harmonizing with the Great Peace. "Empty Azure" denotes the qi of the First Green Heaven. The Cloud Palace’s Yellow Chamber and seven-jeweled curtains adorn the celestial palace. "Savoring and delving" mean to ponder deeply. "Penetrating wisdom generating spirit" encapsulates the essential purport of Daoist scriptures. "Subtle principles of the Great Primordial" signify the profoundest truths, their traces concealed. "Resonant whistling" describes the unfurling of his spirit and the expansiveness of his numinous heart.

At that moment, the Flying Celestial Great Sage, the Boundless Spirit-King, the Jade Assistant and Supreme Steward, and the Four Harmonious Attendants of the Dawn, having purified themselves in fasting and raised their ritual tablets, stood in attendance at his side. Leaning upon his jade countenance, they were moved to wondrous perception; gazing upon his numinous eyes, they opened their hearts. Secretly inspired by the divine chapters, they leapt with joy; feasting upon the celestial sounds, they were reborn. Seizing the moment to awaken to communion, they dared to expose their hearts beneath his numinous gaze.

The Spirit-King, Supreme Steward, and Attendants of the Dawn were all close ministers. The Four Harmonious correspond to the Four Assistants—front and rear, left and right. "Purifying in fasting" means emptying the heart to await inquiry. "Raising ritual tablets" refers to the Spirit-King’s holding of the staff of office, used by decree to summon the myriad spirits. "Jade countenance" signifies flawless purity. "Numinous eyes" and "numinous gaze" denote all-pervading illumination. At this moment, the Spirit-King, gazing upon the Celestial Worthy’s visage and hearing his celestial voice, yearned for the divine chapters. Suddenly enlightened, he seized the opportunity to venture beneath the numinous gaze, laying bare his long-held heart to make his request.

Thereupon, the Flying Celestial Great Sage, the Boundless Spirit-King, stepped forward, bowed deeply, and addressed the Celestial Worthy, saying: "This humble servant, fortunate to attend in your numinous presence, unworthy though I am, has been cleansed in the dark ford, twice awakened to the congealed mystery, and elevated to the rank of Spirit-King. I govern life and death, oversee all celestial immortals, bestow rewards and monitor the Seven Awakenings, gaze afar into distant realms, and in harmonious observation, face the Supreme Steward, answering as Attendant of the Dawn."

The Spirit-King, desiring to request the jade chapters, first offered words to the Celestial Worthy, humbly acknowledging his own limited talents, cleansed of the stains of his heart in the ford of the dark sea. "Twice awakened to the congealed mystery" signifies profound attainment of the most profound profundities. All that follows—"governing life and death" and so on—pertains to the duties of the Spirit-King. "Bestowing rewards and monitoring the Seven Awakenings" refers to carrying out the Celestial Worthy’s mandate to confer favor upon those who cultivate the Way. Master Xiao Zhenyou explains the Seven Awakenings, citing the *Scripture on Stabilizing Contemplation in the Numinous Treasure*: "Those who study the Way pass through seven stages. First, the heart attains stability, easily perceiving all defilements. Second, all long-standing illnesses vanish, and body and mind become light and refreshed. Third, premature depletion is replenished, and one regains one’s years to restore destiny."

Fourth, attaining long life and enduring vision, one is called an Immortal. Fifth, refining the form into qi, one is called a Perfected. Sixth, refining qi into spirit, one is called a Spirit-Person. Seventh, refining spirit to merge with the Dao, one is called a Supreme Person.

Harmonious and concordant—this speaks of one’s duty to maintain harmony, gazing upward to serve the Supreme Steward, as if attending the dawn and responding to its governance.

At the proper moment, one must seize the opportunity and align with the convergence, treading the Nine Great Suns, penetrating the Yin Talisman, and extending a guiding hand to the myriad people. When the great cycle nears its end and the reckoning of *jiashen* arrives, the deluge will scour away filth, and calamities will blanket the heavens. The Three Officials will wield their brushes, assessing and distinguishing the seed-people, examining merits and transgressions, and separating the good from the wicked.

*Opportunity* refers to what precedes an event; *convergence*, to encounter. *Treading* means to act. *Nine* signifies the thorough penetration of yang. *Talisman* means register—here, the extreme of yang gives rise to yin, and one traverses the yin register. The *Three Officials* are those of Heaven, Earth, and Water. Stirring their brush-tips, they distinguish the good and evil of a person’s lifetime to determine blessings or misfortunes.

*Seed-people*—Master Xiao Zhenyou explains: the Four Brahmā Heavens are called the Four Seed-Civilian Heavens, located above the Twenty-Eight Heavens and beyond the reach of the Three Calamities. The Spirit-King, moved by the impending flood disaster of the time, seized the moment to request scriptures, proclaiming the power of the Dao to deliver salvation.

From the era of *Chiming* to the first year of *Shanghuang*, according to the *Primordial Yang Jade Archives*, those who received deliverance numbered 240,000. *Chiming* refers to the time of the *Numinous Treasure’s* deliverance of humanity; *Shanghuang*, to the emergence of the *Divine Treasure* scriptures. *Primordial Yang* is the palace of the Purple Tenuity. The *Nine Dark Jade Archives* contain the statutes of the Perfected, recording the merits and transgressions of people. Those who *received deliverance* were all virtuous.

After *Kaihuang*, when the reckoning reaches *jiashen*, the heavens will select officials in sequence, the offices of the immortals will lie vacant, the ranks of the bureaucracy will be unfilled, and the scattered administrative posts will all await appointed personnel. *Kaihuang* is the name of a celestial kalpa, following *Shanghuang*.

The *Recorder of Destinies* said: "Yesterday, the Eastern Flower gathered all the officials of destiny, the spirits of the land, and the functionaries of the registers to review and assess the records. They found that among the people of the world, those who do good are few—less than one in fifty—let alone those who attain immortality. The offices of the immortals lie vacant, with none worthy of their posts, and even the scattered administrative positions are filled with the indolent. Those found to have transgressions upon examination will have the higher immortals demoted to lower immortals, and the lower immortals stripped of their ranks to become overseers of the underworld, so that they may repent, cultivate diligently, and eventually regain their former positions."

In the past, the Supreme Primordial Lady, having attained the rank of Primordial Lord, neglected her imperial duties, fell short in her proper affairs, transgressed the bounds of propriety, and lost decorum in courtly feasts. For carelessly revealing celestial treasures, she was demoted to a lesser Perfected, her register as a Perfected Sovereign was revoked, and her position in the Purple Void was withdrawn. From this, it is clear that the promotions and demotions of immortal offices are precise to the finest detail.

According to the *Primordial Yang Jade Calendar*, during the Three Generations, those who have accumulated goodness and established merit, who are commended by the Three Realms and vouched for by the Five Emperors, and whose names are recorded in the heavens, shall be selected—100,000 to fill the offices, and an additional 120,000 to serve as reserve officials.

The *Jade Archives* mentioned earlier assess the souls of the deceased, while this *Jade Calendar* records the duties of the immortal offices. The *Three Generations* refer to ancestors who accumulated goodness, selecting those whose merit spans generations to fill the offices of the immortals, with the reserves serving as deputies.

Such examples include those whose names are preordained in the *Mystic Registers*—this is one criterion for selecting immortal officials, taking those whose names are recorded in the heavens, such as Sima Ziwei, whose name appears in the Cinnabar Terrace and Crimson Gates. Others possess bone structures aligned with immortality—those endowed with the pure qi of heaven and earth, born untainted by the mundane, with crane-like necks, tortoise-like jaws, emerald pupils, and double ankles, their bearing ethereal and embracing the mien of soaring clouds. These are the vessels of the Dao’s grove, fully worthy of such selection.

Others attain it through *extinction and rebirth*, their karmic cycles turning—those who cultivated the Dao but had not yet achieved completion before passing are called *extinguished*, yet they may still be promoted to immortal offices. In the past, Zheng Ren’an was born in Chanli and could speak within three days, already knowing his past lives. At twelve, his face radiated jade-like light, and he left home to wander the mountains and forests. Later, he attained extinction in the northern deserts of Rong, achieving fruition and becoming known as the Venerable Lord of Cinnabar Spirit.

Others are deeply devoted to the Three Treasures, their virtuous deeds piercing the heavens. The *Three Treasures* are the Dao, the scriptures, and the masters. The teachings reside within them. Disciples recite their words to illuminate the Dao and transform those who have not yet awakened—this is profound devotion. The *Scripture of the Hidden Perfected* states: "When the nature of greed is stilled and extinguished, and the dusty burdens are untainted, with precepts unbroken, this is called the Treasure of Dharma. When the nature of anger does not arise and one is not enraged by external dust, with concentration unshaken by birth and death, this is called the Treasure of the Master. When the nature of delusion takes nothing, free from vexation and affliction, with wisdom flowing unimpeded, this is called the Treasure of the Dao. When the Three Poisons of greed, anger, and delusion are extinguished, the Three Treasures naturally manifest, and virtuous deeds pierce the heavens."

Others are commended by the Three Officials for their offerings to the Treasure of the Master. The *Master* is one who transmits the Dao, establishes teachings, and expounds scriptures. Since ancient times, immortals and sages have not attained deliverance without a master. Even ordinary people rely on masters to transmit their learning—how could one not revere, trust, and make offerings to them? Serving with diligence and utmost sincerity, earnestly guiding and instructing, one is rightfully commended by the Three Officials.

Others accumulate merit through fasting and upholding precepts. *Fasting* means aligning one’s thoughts, moderating flavors, and preserving wholeness of truth. *Precepts* include the Nine Precepts of the Numinous Treasure and the Ten Precepts of the Orthodox Unity. Upholding them unwaveringly over time accumulates merit and virtue.

Li Changling said: "Daily practice is called *merit*; daily renewal is called *virtue*. The heavenly immortals require 1,300 good deeds—one good deed a day would take only four years. The earthly immortals require 300 good deeds—practicing them would take only a year. Yet most people abandon their efforts midway. Have they not heard of the saying about water wearing through stone or bowing to a tree?"

The Primordial Lady of the Purple Void said: "In the past, Master Fu loved the Dao from his youth and entered a stone chamber on Mount Jiao, where he cultivated for seven years."

Suddenly, the Supreme Pole Perfected One bestowed upon him a wooden drill and commanded him to bore through a massive stone. The Perfected One admonished: "When the stone is pierced, I shall deliver you." The stone measured five *chi* in thickness. Fu drilled without respite, and after forty-seven years, the stone was suddenly pierced through. The Perfected One indeed came to deliver him.

The Lady of Southern Marchmount said: "In ancient times, there was a man who roused his resolve for the Dao yet knew not the method of seeking it. Day and night, he bowed to a withered tree. After twenty-eight years, the tree suddenly bloomed, and its sap flowed like honey. The man took the blossoms and sap and consumed them, thereby attaining longevity.
